entry.title: How to upload the value in Assignment level custom field in bulk in SF Variable pay template
entry.content:
Hi ,

My Client would like to update Max opportunity level , which is part of Assignment level section in a Variable Pay template.

The "Max opportunity level %" is pulled through Lookup table. However for some exceptions, Local admins could upload the Max opportunity level manually through bulk import.

Then A custom formula in Assignment level section would select the appropriate Max opportunity level %. This solution is working as expected when the Override field for Max opportunity level % is updated in Executive review. However since "Bonus payout details" file can't be imported in Executive review is there any solution to update this Override field in Assignment level section in bulk by Local admins?

Regards,

Srikrishna.

entry.title: Re: How to configure Withholding Tax code 197A Exemption...
entry.content:
You can configure this requirement in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud by defining two separate Withholding Tax Codes under Section 197A, each with its own threshold and rate. One code will apply 0.7% up to ₹2 crore, and the other will apply 1% above ₹2 crore. The system allows you to set minimum/maximum amounts and cumulative thresholds at the vendor level to automate this.

Follow the below steps

1. Define Withholding Tax Type
Create or use an existing Withholding Tax Type for Section 197A. Ensure it is linked to the relevant company code and jurisdiction. This type will act as the umbrella under which multiple tax codes are defined.

2. Create two Withholding Tax Codes
Tax Code 1 @ 0.7%. Maximum cumulative threshold: ₹2 crore. This ensures the system applies 0.7% only until the supplier’s payments reach ₹2 crore.

Tax Code 2 @ 1%. Minimum cumulative threshold: ₹2 crore + 1. This ensures the higher rate applies once the threshold is crossed. SAP documentation Overview of Settings for Withholding Tax  confirms that you can configure minimum and maximum amounts within WHT codes to enforce thresholds.

3. Assign Withholding Tax Type/Code to Supplier Master
In Business Partner Master Data, assign the relevant WHT type and codes to suppliers who fall under Section 197A. This ensures the system automatically applies the correct rate depending on cumulative payments.

4. Activate Threshold Tracking
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud supports cumulative threshold tracking per vendor annually. This means the system will monitor payments across the financial year and switch from 0.7% to 1% once the ₹2 crore threshold is breached.

5. Testing & Validation
Post a test invoice below ₹2 crore → system should apply 0.7%. Post invoices cumulatively exceeding ₹2 crore → system should automatically switch to 1%. Validate in Withholding Tax Reporting to ensure compliance.

Please take the below as Key considerations

  • Scope Item Activation: Ensure the scope item for Extended Withholding Tax (1J2) is activated in your tenant.
  • Annual Reset: Thresholds reset at the start of each financial year, so configuration must align with Indian statutory requirements.
  • Supplier-Specific: Apply only to suppliers eligible under Section 197A; others may need different codes (e.g., 194C, 194J).

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint
entry.content:
Implementing AI in SAP SuccessFactors in 2026: A Practical, Customer-Ready Roadmap

From Strategy → Activation → Adoption → Scale

Key Takeaways (Please take a moment to read this first)

  • AI in SuccessFactors is not one switch. Treat it as Joule + embedded module AI + (optionally) Joule Studio extensions.
  • Do not start with configuration. Start with 5 to 10 prioritized use cases, persona-based KPIs, and a risk rating.
  • RBP is the real bottleneck. If permissions are wrong, adoption fails (or security risk increases).
  • Skills intelligence (TIH) is often the fastest value path. But only if job architecture + skills governance are ready.
  • Governance is non-negotiable in 2026. Human-in-the-loop, auditability, and privacy readiness prevent AI from getting paused.
  • Pilot with evidence-based gates. Scale only after metrics prove value and guardrails.

Table of Contents

  • Executive Summary
  • 1) Defining “AI in SuccessFactors” for 2026
  • 2) The #1 Mistake: Technology-First Thinking
  • 3) Commercial & Platform Readiness (Before Configuration)
  • 4) Technical Prerequisites & Architectural Readiness
  • 5) Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) AI: Fastest Path to Measurable Value
  • 6) The 8-Phase Implementation Roadmap
  • 7) Governance You Must Have in 2026 (Or AI Will Get Paused)
  • Adoption Challenges & Failure Recovery Paths
  • 9) Timelines & Resource Requirements
  • 10) What to Communicate to Leadership
  • Conclusion
  • Appendix: Quick Reference Templates
  • One-Page Implementation Checklist

Executive Summary

This guide translates SAP SuccessFactors AI capabilities into a disciplined, evidence-based implementation path. It addresses the critical gap between technical deployment and organizational value realization -- where most initiatives stall. The framework balances strategic depth (architectural decisions, licensing, data governance) with pragmatic adoption mechanics (change management, pilot gates, skills lifecycle governance).

Key Premise: AI success is determined 40% by change management, 25% by technology, and 35% by data readiness & organizational alignment. Technical enablement is necessary, not sufficient.

1) Defining “AI in SuccessFactors” for 2026

SAP’s AI strategy in SuccessFactors operates across three integrated layers. Understanding the boundaries and dependencies between layers is essential for licensing, governance, and adoption planning.

Layer A: Joule — The Conversational AI Copilot

What it is: A role-aware conversational interface embedded across SuccessFactors, running on SAP BTP. Joule understands user role, context, and permissions, then helps employees navigate, retrieve information, and complete tasks through natural language.

Conversational patterns (all three are supported):

  • Navigation: “How do I access my compensation statement?”
  • Transactions: “Create a time-off request for Feb 10–14”
  • Information retrieval: “What’s my manager’s approval status on my promotion?”

Security Strength: Joule respects Role-Based Permissions (RBP) boundaries. It cannot return data a user should not see, even if requested. This requires careful RBP design (covered in Section 4).

2026 roadmap (example set): Performance & Goals Agent, Career & Talent Development Agent, People Intelligence Agent, HR Service Agent, Payroll Agent.

Strategic signal: Accelerating shift from traditional UI to conversational interaction.

Layer B: Embedded AI Features Inside Modules

These are AI capabilities tightly integrated into specific SuccessFactors modules. They don’t require Joule but add intelligence to traditional workflows.

  • Recruiting: AI-assisted job description generation, candidate scoring
  • Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH): Skill extraction, skill inferencing, skill standardization
  • Performance & Goals: Writing assistance, goal feedback suggestions
  • Learning: Course recommendations
  • Succession & Talent Development: Internal mobility recommendations

Licensing reality: Most embedded AI features require premium licensing (often via AI Units). Base SuccessFactors includes limited AI functionality.

Layer C: Extending AI with Joule Studio

What it is: A low-code, visual builder (part of SAP Build) for creating custom Joule skills and agents.

  • Skills: Deterministic, structured tasks (e.g., standardize job level from a requisition)
  • Agents: Multi-step, goal-oriented workflows requiring judgment (e.g., recommend internal candidates for a role)

When to use: When Layers A and B don’t cover differentiating workflows. Plan this later (typically Phase 7).

2) The #1 Mistake Customers Make: Technology-First Thinking

The common pattern: enable Joule, configure TIH, launch… then adoption plateaus and investment doesn’t scale. Root cause is prioritizing technology over outcomes, change management, and data readiness.

Outcome-Focused Use-Case Framework (by Persona)

Employees (Self-Service)

  • “How do I…?” questions grounded in HR policies and navigation
  • Policy Q&A with escalation paths
  • Content support: resume help, goal drafting, learning recommendations
  • Guardrails: AI should not make talent decisions (promotion, pay) without escalation

Managers

  • Coaching assistance (draft feedback, goal coaching)
  • People questions with proper authorization
  • Succession and development recommendations (permission-aware)
  • Guardrails: AI suggests; managers decide; recommendations labeled AI-assisted

HR / Centers of Expertise

  • Skills intelligence for planning (trending skills, gaps)
  • Internal mobility insights
  • Recruiting productivity improvements
  • Analytics-style Q&A (where available)

Governance integrity requirement: AI-assisted decisions (pay, promotion, termination) must be human-reviewed and documented.

Use-Case Scorecard (Phase 0 Deliverable)

Attribute                           Example

Use CasePolicy Q&A for employees
PersonaEmployee, all levels
Target Population5,000 active users
Data DependenciesHR policies + org structure
Risk RatingLow (informational)
KPIDAU 30% in 6 months; support ticket reduction 15%
Adoption BarrierTrust in answer accuracy
MitigationChampion loop + escalation path

3) Commercial & Platform Readiness (Before Configuration)

Principle: Understand licensing obligations and data governance constraints before building. Changing course mid-implementation is costly.

3.1 AI Units Licensing: The 2026 Reality

Premium AI capabilities are commonly packaged and consumed via AI Units. Establish consumption governance early to avoid budget surprises.

Feature AI Units                                                  Required?          Notes

Joule (copilot/agents)Yes (Premium)Interactions may consume AI Units (validate per contract)
TIH advanced AI (extraction/inferencing)Yes (Premium)Advanced TIH capabilities typically require AI Units
Writing assistance (basic)Often NoMay be included depending on edition / scope

Budgeting recommendation: baseline consumption in pilot, model scale-up, implement approvals for premium feature enablement, and budget contingency for usage creep.

3.2 Regional Compliance & Data Residency

If you operate across borders (especially EU/UK), data residency and cross-border processing obligations can impact timeline and design. Start legal/privacy work early (privacy impact assessment, DPA updates, audit expectations).

4) Technical Prerequisites & Architectural Readiness

Principle: Joule and TIH integration requires alignment across SuccessFactors, SAP Cloud Identity Services, and SAP BTP.

4.1 Three-Pillar Infrastructure

  • Pillar 1: SAP SuccessFactors — release readiness, platform configuration, RBP maturity
  • Pillar 2: SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) — authentication, SSO, provisioning
  • Pillar 3: SAP BTP — foundation for Joule services, setup automation/boosters, integrations

Project reality check: This is cross-platform, not only SuccessFactors. Plan admin roles and ownership across HR, IT, Identity, and Security.

4.2 Role-Based Permissions (RBP): The Strategic Bottleneck

RBP is not a checkbox. It is the mechanism that determines what Joule can show and do for each user. If RBP is too permissive, you risk exposure. If too restrictive, adoption collapses.

RBP Architecture (Three-Element Framework)

  • Permission Groups (static/dynamic)
  • Permission Roles (bundled permissions)
  • Target Populations (data scoping)

RBP Implementation Sequence (Industry Standard)

Phase       Duration         Key Activities                                                        Owner

Design3–4 weeksStakeholder interviews, role/target modelHR/IT/Security
Build2–3 weeksConfigure groups/roles/targetsSF Admin/RBP Specialist
Test3–4 weeksPersona testing, SoD checks, edge casesQA/Security/Compliance
Deploy1–2 weeksRulebook, admin training, go-liveProject Team
OngoingContinuousMonthly governance + quarterly auditIT Ops/Internal Audit

4.3 Joule Onboarding Pathway (Technical Activation)

  1. Run BTP setup (booster-led or guided): provision Joule services and validate connectivity
  2. Enable “Access to Joule” via RBP: start with pilot groups
  3. Execute the guided mission/setup steps: complete configuration and testing scenarios
  4. Validate user experience: confirm Joule is visible for pilot users; test permission boundaries

5) Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) AI: The Fastest Path to Measurable Value

If you want measurable HR outcomes (hiring speed, internal mobility, workforce planning), TIH is often the best starting point because it connects skills intelligence to real HR decisions and workflows.

What TIH AI Does

  • Skill Extraction: from job profiles, requisitions, resumes; creates normalized skills library
  • Skill Inferencing: infers skills from activities/achievements/feedback; recommends to employees
  • Standardization & Governance: deduplicate and manage taxonomy; govern lifecycle inferred → confirmed

The Skills Governance Workflow (Critical)

  1. Enable TIH AI capabilities in admin configuration
  2. Run initial extraction and build skills library
  3. Review and standardize: merge duplicates; build taxonomy
  4. Enable inferencing and define decision rules
  5. Establish cadence: monthly review; quarterly audit; annual refresh

Most common failure: “We’ll clean job architecture later.” Dirty job architecture produces low-quality skill signals and user distrust. Clean critical job architecture inputs before scaling TIH AI.

6) The 8-Phase Implementation Roadmap

Core principle: Each phase has success criteria and decision gates. Scale only when evidence supports it.

Phase 0: AI Readiness Assessment (Weeks 1–2)

  • Top 5 use cases + KPIs
  • Data maturity assessment (job architecture, org graph quality, skills readiness)
  • Privacy & compliance assessment
  • High-level architecture sketch (SF ↔ IAS ↔ BTP ↔ Joule)
  • Pilot scope and exit criteria

Phase 1: Commercial & Entitlements (Weeks 3–5)

  • Confirm premium AI needs and consumption governance
  • Confirm region/data residency constraints
  • Finalize legal/DPA requirements

Phase 2: Identity & Access Foundation (Weeks 6–11)

  • IAS readiness (or migration as needed)
  • RBP design/build/test and security sign-off
  • Pilot user groups defined
  • Audit/logging expectations documented

Phase 3: Core Joule Onboarding (Weeks 12–14)

  • Provision Joule services
  • Enable Access to Joule for pilot group
  • Validate guardrails + audit readiness
  • UAT with pilot personas

Phase 4: “Safe Pilot” Launch (12-week pilot)

  • Controlled rollout to 100–500 users
  • Track DAU, helpfulness, escalations, support tickets, sentiment
  • Decision gate: Go / Hold / Pause and redesign

Phase 5: Skills Intelligence Activation (TIH) (4-week intensive + ongoing)

  • Enable extraction + inferencing
  • Standardize taxonomy
  • Establish monthly governance cadence

Phase 6: Premium AI Use-Case Expansion (Weeks 43–52)

  • Expand to new BUs/regions only after pilot evidence
  • Implement monthly usage governance + ROI tracking

Phase 7: Extend with Joule Studio (Optional) (8–16 weeks)

  • Build custom skills/agents for differentiating workflows
  • Security review + edge case testing

Phase 8: Operate, Monitor & Continuously Improve (Ongoing)

  • Weekly ops review
  • Monthly adoption + consumption review
  • Quarterly roadmap alignment
  • Annual ROI assessment

7) Governance You Must Have in 2026 (Or AI Will Get Paused)

7.1 Responsible AI Framework (Non-Negotiable)

Control                                   Implementation                                                                                                                   Owner

Human-in-the-LoopTalent-impacting decisions require human approval and documentationHR + Managers
Audit TrailsLog who asked what, outputs, approvals, and actions; align retention policyIT + Compliance
Data MinimizationOnly use the data needed; restrict sensitive fields unless requiredData Architect
Bias/Outcome ReviewQuarterly audits to detect disparate impact and remediateHR Analytics + Compliance
Escalation ProtocolDefine triggers for HR Legal/Compliance escalationHR Legal

7.2 Lightweight AI Center of Excellence (COE)

  • HR Product Owner: value + adoption
  • SF Platform Lead: configuration + RBP + release planning
  • BTP/Identity Lead: IAS + BTP operations
  • Governance/Compliance: audit + privacy + controls
  • Change Manager: enablement + comms + feedback loops

Adoption Challenges & Failure Recovery Paths

Failure Mode 1: Pilot Success, Scale Stall

  • Root causes: sheltered pilot population, uneven data quality by region, change management not scalable, guardrails misfit
  • Recovery: pause expansion, diagnose by cohort, fix root causes, phased rollout with monitoring gates

Failure Mode 2: Skills Governance Breakdown

  • Root causes: dirty job architecture, unclear ownership, inconsistent approval rules
  • Recovery: pause, clean taxonomy, define decision rules, assign ownership and cadence

Failure Mode 3: RBP Security Incident

  • Root causes: misconfigured target populations
  • Recovery: disable, audit access, fix RBP, retest, add monthly RBP audit

Failure Mode 4: Budget Overage & Licensing Surprise

  • Root causes: usage creep, adoption growth, unplanned premium features
  • Recovery: analyze consumption drivers, prioritize ROI, throttle low-ROI features, strengthen approval governance

9) Realistic Timelines & Resource Requirements

Overall Timeline (Typical)

Phase                          Duration                       Key Resource Gap

Phase 02 weeksProgram manager + architect
Phase 13 weeksProcurement + finance alignment
Phase 26 weeksRBP specialist
Phase 33 weeksSF admin + IT
Phase 412 weeksChange leadership + pilot champions
Phase 54 weeks + ongoingData/skills governance owner
Phase 64 weeksOps + governance scale
Phase 7 (optional)8–16 weeksSAP Build developer
Phase 8OngoingLean COE

10) What to Communicate to Leadership (Executive Summary)

The Business Case (Illustrative)

  • HR productivity: 10–15% reduction in operations time
  • Manager effectiveness: shift time from admin to coaching
  • Internal mobility: increase internal fills via skills visibility and recommendations

The Risk Summary

Risk                                                            Likelihood                                                                            Mitigation

Adoption stallsModerateInvest in change management; evidence-based gates
Data quality issues at scaleModeratePhase 0 data assessment; clean job architecture
RBP misconfigurationLow if Phase 2 done wellDo not skip RBP testing; monthly audit
Budget overageModerateConsumption governance; ROI-based enablement
Compliance gapLow with governancePrivacy assessment + audit trails + HitL

Conclusion

Implementing AI in SuccessFactors is not primarily a technology problem; it is an organizational change and data readiness problem. Technical enablement is table stakes. The decisive factors are:

  • Change management rigor (drives adoption)
  • Data readiness (drives answer and recommendation quality)
  • Technology execution (enables secure, scalable experiences)

Start with Phase 0. Don’t skip Phase 2 (RBP). Invest in change management throughout.

Appendix: Quick Reference Templates

Phase 0 Use-Case Scorecard (Template)

Use Case: [Name]
Persona: [Employee/Manager/HR/Other]
Target Population: [# of users]
Data Dependencies: [What data is needed?]
Risk Rating: [Low/Medium/High]
KPI / Success Metric: [Specific, measurable metric]
Adoption Barrier: [What will prevent adoption?]
Mitigation: [How will you overcome barrier?]
Executive Owner: [Name, Title]

Phase 4 Pilot Success Metrics (Template)

Metric | Target | Week 6 Actual | Week 12 Actual | Status
DAU (%) | >20% | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗
Escalation Rate | <10% | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗
User Sentiment | Positive | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗
Support Tickets | Flat or declining | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗
Data Quality Issues | None | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗
Guardrails Validated | All pass | ___ | ___ | ✓/✗

Go/No-Go Decision: [Go to Phase 5 / Hold / No-Go]
Rationale: [Explain decision]
Next Steps: [List actions]

RBP Design Worksheet (Template)

Permission Group | User Type | Selection Criteria | Target Population for Roles | Owner | Status
Finance/Payroll Managers | Manager | Dept=Finance, Level≥7 | Can view Finance employee data; edit compensation | [Name] | Draft
Sales Reps | Employee | Dept=Sales | View own records; access company policies | [Name] | Draft

One-Page Implementation Checklist

Use this as a program control sheet. The goal is to avoid “pilot excitement” turning into “scale failure.”

Workstream            Checklist Item                                               Exit Criteria                                                                  Owner                             Status

StrategyTop 5 AI use cases prioritized (by persona)Use-case scorecards approved + KPIs definedHR Product Owner⬜
Risk & CompliancePrivacy/data assessment completedLegal/Compliance sign-off + documented controlsCompliance Lead⬜
CommercialPremium AI / AI Units scope confirmed (if applicable)Consumption governance defined (approval + monitoring)Procurement/Finance⬜
IdentityIAS readiness and SSO approach finalizedAuth flows validated + admin roles assignedIdentity Lead⬜
SecurityRBP design/build/test completedPersona tests pass + SoD checks + audit evidenceSF Platform Lead⬜
TechnicalJoule onboarding/setup completed (BTP + SF)Joule visible for pilot + guardrails validatedBTP Lead / SF Admin⬜
PilotSafe pilot launched (100–500 users)DAU + helpfulness + escalation targets metChange Manager⬜
Data & SkillsJob architecture + skills governance ready (TIH)Taxonomy owner assigned + cadence establishedHR COE / Data Owner⬜
ScaleExpansion gate decisionGo/Hold/No-Go documented with evidenceAI COE⬜

entry.title: Re: aATP - Confirmation Strategies
entry.content:
Redistribute strategy should be used if the orders are considered on first come, first served basis. But, please consider the fact that redistribute can unconfirm something which is about to ship soon. So, that can be taken care by further introducing a lock or priority rule for orders that meet certain criteria, such as:

  • Status = Ready to Ship or Confirmed
  • Shipping date within X hours/days
  • Already picked or packed

reloaded due to memory constraint often comes when the mobile OS ( iOS /Android) is low on Ram. Reloading happens to free up RAM. entry.title: Re: Assignment to a profitability segment has no effect f...
entry.content:
To get details about (and options for) submitting your questions to SAP Community, please see the Asking and Answering Questions in the Community After Migration post in the What's New section. You may also want to watch How do I ask a question from a category page?, as this how-to video illustrates one approach for posting a question to SAP Community.
Before you ask a question, please browse the community in case this question has been answered already.
If you need to create a new question, start with a descriptive title that briefly outlines what your question is about. A clear question title will help community members gain a quick initial understanding of your question. It will also help community members find your question (and its answers) when they are searching for solutions to similar problems.
When writing your question, please share what steps you took that led you to your question. If you don't, community members might tell you to take actions you've already tried yourself.
Make sure that your question is very specific. Provide as many details as you can -- such as which product version you are using and what error message you're receiving. Include screenshots if possible.

Since you have not indicated in which version you are working ( ECC or S/4HANA), check SAP note 3562180 (if yours is S/4) and see whether you need to carry out code corrections as recommended in this note.

entry.title: Extending Standard Timesheet v4 App Using SAPUI5 Adaptation Project in BAS – Is
entry.content:
Hello Experts @Andr @ThomasQ @SUPPORT2  

We are using the standard Manage My Timesheet Fiori application in SAP S/4HANA 2023 On-Premise.
Now I have a requirement to extend this standard app using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

 

Requirement
I need to implement custom UI logic so that the Draft mode is automatically enabled whenever the user starts creating or editing a timesheet entry.

Currently, users must manually click the “Enable Draft” checkbox, which is often missed.

Questions
Is it possible to extend the standard Timesheet app (Manage My Timesheet) using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project for an on-premise S/4HANA system?

After adapting the UI in BAS, can we deploy the variant back to the on-premise ABAP repository?

Do we need to configure SAP Cloud Connector + BTP Destination for BAS to access the on-premise S/4 system?

Is the controller extension the correct place to implement logic for auto-enabling Draft mode?

Are there any known limitations or best practices when using an adaptation project specifically for the Timesheet application?

My Understanding (Please Confirm)
Adaptation Projects are supported for S/4HANA on-premise if prerequisites (SAP_UI version, UI5 version, no scaffolding app, etc.) are fulfilled.

Deployment requires an ABAP package and Transport Request.

BAS requires system connectivity through Cloud Connector + Destination using

Controller extension should allow injecting custom logic to auto-enable draft mode.

Info about timesheet ;

Title  : My Timesheet
ID       :F3074A
Version  : 12.3.25
Component  : PA-FIO-TS
Technical Component ID  : hcm.fio.mytimesheets1
Framework ID : UI5
Framework Version : 1.120.23 (202411061204)

Request
Before setting up Cloud Connector and BTP Destinations, I want to confirm whether this approach is the correct and supported way to enhance the Timesheet app, and whether anyone has implemented similar customizations.

Any guidance, confirmation, or documentation reference would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

Arbaj Shekh

entry.title: Re: Using XDL to purge data from Stage Tables in SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management
entry.content:
We implemented it like: a data extract provides us with a file in Pipeline-template format containing all batches in stage in which are older than x days. we pick up the file, delete all rows which exceed a tbd limit (e.g. 20) and put the file back to the inbound dropbox. Then 20 purge pipelines are triggered. 
As long as the limit is higher than your average number of files which you load per day, you will see that you end up in a stage-table history which is not exceeding the x days.

entry.title: UKISUG & Customer Support Day: SAP Support Powers Real-World Success
entry.content:
Wishes alone don’t deliver real-world results. Real business outcomes demand action, and that’s why the UKISUG & Customer Support Day in February will highlight how support helps businesses reach major achievements.

In the session “Your Guide to Driving Real Business Outcomes”, we’ll discover how SAP Enterprise Support Academy and SAP Enterprise Support value maps help customers overcome complexity, accelerate adoption, and realize measurable value across their SAP landscape.

SAP Enterprise Support provides advisory, learning, and focused services tailored to customers’ business functions and needs, while delivering actionable insights that clear the path to adoption, agility, and growth for all cloud customers. Through the SAP Community, customers can find an intuitive, social, and collaborative environment to develop the know-how required to maximize their investment, with access to curated knowledge, blog posts, events, and even request a call with an expert.

This journey is supported by SAP Cloud ALM, the platform that champions transformation, operations, adoption, and lifecycle management. Integrated with SAP Enterprise Support, it guides customers to confidently implement best practices and manage their SAP landscape efficiently.

An AI-enabled support model further enhances this experience through three pillars:

  • Empowered Support: Simplifies self-service and advisory content.
  • Invisible Support: Prevents issues by identifying risks early.
  • Accelerated Support: Reduces resolution time significantly.

Together, these capabilities offer fast problem solving, rich empowerment, prescriptive guidance, and a seamless experience across SAP’s cloud products and digital channels.

If you want to help shape the next wave of support innovation, join us at the UKISUG & Customer Support Day on February 26 and find out how SAP Support can drive real-world success.

entry.title: Re: I am unable to access my SAP BTP Trial account
entry.content:
While you are waiting for a fix to be provided, you can still access your trial account in BTP cockpit by directly opening the global account:

https://cockpit.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial/#/globalaccount/

This link should redirect you to your global account. In case it does not, you can try providing your global account id as well, but it should not be required:

https://cockpit.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial/#/globalaccount/<your-global-account-GUID>

If you do not have your account's GUID at hand, you can retrieve it via the "Network" tab in your browser developer tools by inspecting the response to the "/ajax/getTrialGlobalAccountList" call.

entry.title: Let’s test RPT-1 on Titanic
entry.content:
How do you test SAP's RPT-1 model beyond a simple Hello World example? Its claim to fame is that it can replace traditional machine learning models for classification and regression tasks. No model training, no hyperparameter tuning, just show it your data and it predicts. That's a bold promise that deserves testing!

Back when I started learning about machine learning, one of my first projects was tackling Kaggle's Titanic Challenge in which you get a dataset with information about the passengers of the Titanic and you have to predict which of them survived. It's not a classic SAP use case, but I think it makes a good first benchmark: To score well, you typically need to clean data, engineer features, and iterate on your model. Would RPT-1 perform well on raw data? Could I improve results by tuning the input? To find out, I decided to board the Titanic again. Here's what I discovered.

Spoiler Alert: RPT-1 performed well, and I learned a lot about how RPT-1 works, including a bit of mystery and surprise. If you are looking for technical details, I have posted Coding Walkthrough on GitHub. In this blog post, I will focus on the insights and lessons learned. So let's jump right in.

 
 

How RPT-1 works

If you haven't worked with RPT-1 before, here's the basic idea: It uses in-context learning, similar to how Large Language Models work. Instead of training a model on your data, you show it examples, and it learns the patterns on the fly without any traditional training step. Think of it like showing a child examples before asking them to solve a new problem.

For the Titanic challenge, this means we give RPT-1 a table of passengers where we know if they survived or not. Then we add one or more row(s) for passengers where survival is unknown, masking the "Survived" fields with a [PREDICT] placeholder. Therefore, the model looks at the patterns in the known data and fills in the blanks.

Here's what a simple (and simplified) payload looks like: (For the full payload structure, please refer to the Coding Walkthrough.)

{
    "prediction_config": {
        "target_columns": [{
            "name": "Survived",
            "prediction_placeholder": "[PREDICT]"
        }]
    },
    "index_column": "PassengerId",
    "rows": [
        {"PassengerId": 1, "Pclass": 3, "Sex": "male", "Age": 22, "Survived": "0"},
        {"PassengerId": 2, "Pclass": 1, "Sex": "female", "Age": 38, "Survived": "1"},
        {"PassengerId": 3, "Pclass": 3, "Sex": "female", "Age": 26, "Survived": "[PREDICT]"}
    ]
}

The model sees that passenger 1 (male, 3rd class) didn't survive, passenger 2 (female, 1st class) did. Now it can use these patterns (women and higher classes survived more often) to predict passenger 3. Pretty elegant, right?

Here is an example of how the prediction result looks like:

[
  {
    "PassengerId": 3,
    "Survived": [
      {
        "confidence": 0.89,
        "prediction": "1"
      }
    ]
  }
]

RPT-1 therefore predicts that passenger 3 survived with a confidence of 89%. A few things stand out here: First, you didn't have to train a model to get this result. Second, that confidence score is actually meaningful. Sure, you could ask an LLM "how confident are you?" and it would happily give you a number, but that's just another token prediction, making up a plausible-sounding answer. RPT-1's confidence comes from the actual probability distribution over possible values produced by the model, which is a fundamentally different (and more useful) thing.

 
 

Experimenting with Training Data

Since Kaggle limits you to 10 submissions per day, and I wanted to run a lot more experiments, I initially planned to only work on the training data where we know the ground truth, masking some "Survived" values, and see if RPT-1 could predict them. This way I could measure performance without burning through my daily submission quota.

Technically, my plan worked perfectly. The results, however, were... suspicious. When I masked 400 out of 891 rows and asked RPT-1 to fill them in, it predicted with 98% accuracy. To put that in perspective: the simple baseline of "women survive, men don't" gets you about 76%. Anything above 80% is highly competitive, and no serious Kaggle submission breaks 90%. A traditional Gradient Boosting model I trained on the same data scored around 80%. So either RPT-1 is doing something magical, or something fishy is going on.

My first thought: Maybe RPT-1 has seen the Titanic dataset during training and is simply regurgitating the answers? To test this, I tried predicting passenger names instead of survival. Names are completely random, so if RPT-1 memorized the dataset, it should nail them too - but it didn't. Instead, it predicted names from the unmasked rows in its context window, with very low confidence. A similar test with ticket numbers (which have some patterns since families shared tickets) showed modest results. RPT-1 was clearly pattern-matching from context, not memorizing from training.

But that still didn't explain the 98% accuracy on survival predictions. So I ran one more experiment: What happens when I severely limit the context? I kept only 2 unmasked rows (the minimum allowed) and tried three variations:

  • One survivor, one non-survivor in context → reasonable predictions
  • Two survivors in context → predicted everyone survived
  • Two non-survivors in context → predicted everyone died

The result was reassuring: RPT-1 was only predicting values it had seen in the context window (same as we had seen with names and ticket numbers). It also "resisted" creating a near-perfect result (scoring 68%) when both "0" and "1" were in the context, even though this would have opened the door for regurgitation.

When I tested how much context RPT-1 needed to produce competitive results, it already scored 85% on the test data with only 20 unmasked entries in the context window (surprisingly high!). With only 20 examples out of 891, the model shouldn't have enough signal generalize well and to outperform Gradient Boosting trained on 491 examples. Put simply, it improved too much. Why? Honestly, I still don't fully understand it. The mystery remains unsolved. If you have a theory, I'd love to hear it. But rather than speculate further, I decided to move on to what really matters: How would RPT-1 perform when it actually had to predict unknown outcomes (the test set)?

 
 

The Real Test: Kaggle Submissions

Time to put RPT-1 to the real test. I combined the training data (with known outcomes) and test data (with [PREDICT] placeholders), sent it to RPT-1, and submitted the predictions to Kaggle.

With raw data and zero preprocessing, RPT-1 scored 0.76555, matching the gender-based baseline. If you've tried this competition yourself, you know that's actually not trivial. Many first attempts fall short of even this baseline.

Next, I tried some standard feature engineering: Extracting titles from names, creating family size indicators, binning ages. Surprisingly, the score barely budged (0.76794). In fact, adding just the Title feature actually dropped the score to 0.76076. This suggested RPT-1 was already extracting similar signals from the raw data, or perhaps the additional columns were adding noise.

Knowing that higher score should be achievable, I created more advanced features that capture social context, for example survival rates of passengers sharing the same surname or ticket number. Indeed, the score increased significantly to 0.78229. But how does this compare to traditional machine learning approaches? Let's find out.

 
 

How Does This Compare to Traditional ML?

To compare RPT-1's scores (small and large) with traditional ML, I trained Gradient Boosting models along the way for comparison using the same engineered features we gave to RPT-1. Here is the full result table for the different setups:

SetupRPT-1-SmallRPT-1-LargeGradientBoosting
No feature engineering0.765550.76555—
With title feature0.760760.76076—
Full feature engineering0.767940.767940.76555
Advanced feature engineering0.779900.782290.77751

Interestingly, both model sizes scored identically on simpler setups, with RPT-1-Large only pulling ahead with advanced features. This may indicate that the small model might be good enough for a dataset of ~1000 lines, but clearly this needs more testing with different use cases. Overall RPT-1-Large wins, even if it's only by ~0.3% compared RPT-1-Small or ~0.5% compared to Gradient Boosting, this is a real difference in this competition.

But the scores only tell half the story. The more interesting story is how RPT-1 wins. When I first trained Gradient Boosting with the advanced features, it actually scored lower than the baseline — classic overfitting. I had to add cross-validation, tune hyperparameters, and simplify the feature set to get to 0.77751. That's the normal ML workflow: train, evaluate, iterate, repeat.

Using RPT-1 I could just add the new features and got results. No retraining, no hyperparameter tuning, no overfitting headaches. The same features that caused Gradient Boosting to overfit worked fine for RPT-1 out of the box.

This advantage compounds in real-world scenarios. Imagine your customer data changes weekly. With traditional ML, that's weekly retraining jobs, validation runs, and deployment cycles. With RPT-1, you just update the context. Whether this holds for enterprise use cases remains to be tested, but the potential is significant and it would fundamentally simplify the operational model.

 
 

Conclusion

RPT-1 didn't just survive the Titanic test, it came out a winner. What can we learn from this exercise? I think we need to look at this from two angles: How does RPT-1 compare to traditional ML models and how does it compare to LLMs.

SAP positions RPT-1 as a replacement for traditional ML models. And it does deliver on that promise. Without any training, it matched and slightly outperformed a tuned Gradient Boosting model. That's remarkable. You can throw structured data at it and get competitive predictions without a typical Machine Learning workflow: No model selection, no hyperparameter tuning, no train-test splits to manage.

Feature engineering still matters, but differently. Basic features like extracting titles barely moved the needle, RPT-1 already seemed to pick up these patterns from the raw data. But features capturing deeper structure (like group survival rates in this case) made a real difference. Zooming out, this saves time and effort when implementing a use case, but meaningful features which focus on domain insights and which aren't obvious still are worth engineering.

We could also see an additional workflow advantage when Gradient Boosting overfit on my advanced features. To really make use of the new features, I had to iterate and add cross-validation, tune parameters, simplify the feature set. With RPT-1, the same features just worked. This is nice for quick experiments (like Titanic), but when projecting this forward into production systems that need regular updates with new data, that's potentially transformative.

SAP also calls RPT-1 a foundation model (for tabular data), so how does it compare to an LLM? As we have seen its output is quite different from that of an LLM, but it is worth noting that, unlike LLMs, RPT-1 produces deterministic results. You can run the same payload multiple times and get the same result. This is a big advantage over LLMs, where you always get slightly different answers. Additionally, RPT-1 produces real confidence scores, something an LLM cannot do. Both of these points clearly make RPT-1 a different kind of model, giving you LLM-style in-context learning, but with ML-style predictive results.

The 98% mystery on masked training data remains. If you have a theory, I'd love to hear it. Nonetheless, my overall impression of RPT-1 is very good and I am looking forward to moving beyond the small Titanic dataset to more enterprise-like use cases to see how RPT-1 performs on more complex scenarios. What enterprise scenarios would you like to see tested?

entry.title: Fiori F3193 Pack Outbound Deliveries – serial number on Warehouse Level not working/supported
entry.content:
The customer I support currently uses /scwm/pack. Now we wanted to switch to Fiori F3193 Pack Outbound Deliveries (SAP S/4HANA 2023 Onprem). The customer has many serialised materials (Harmonised Serial Number Profiles) and these are set to ‘Serial Number Requirement B - On Warehouse Number Level’.

When testing, I now get the error message ‘can't pack products with serial numbers defined at warehouse level’! When I create profiles with A or C (A > Serial Number Requirement For Document Item or C > Serial Number Requirement On Stock Level), it works!

The interesting thing is that it works fine with /scwm/pack! Furthermore, according to the list here, repacking should be possible https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/9832125c23154a179bfa1784cdc9577a/80419bed7dc048498e35db4b38f60dfc.html?locale=en-US 

Is this really how SAP designed it? If so, is there a trick to fix it? Because we can't just switch to A or C!

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in December
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in December

What a year it has been. Wow! 2025 was packed with great events, lots of new features and enhancements to extend existing features, and the launch of SAP Business Data Cloud. 
Explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and enjoy watching my top feature highlights for 2025 on YouTube 📺 below.

 

SAP Datasphere 2025 highlights in a nutshell

What a great ride it has been in 2025 with SAP Datasphere!
Let me share a few of my personal highlights.

SAP Business Data Cloud

The announcement of SAP Business Data Cloud in February this year made quite some noise and puts data, analytics and AI at the center of our portfolio at SAP. We delivered SAP Business Data Cloud in May 2025 as a fully managed software as a service solution that unifies and governs all SAP data and seamlessly connects with third-party data.

It is an evolution of the business data fabric journey we started with SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud some years ago and also offers a path forward for your investments in SAP BW.

Delivering out-of-the-box always-on data products is the next pivotal step in our data strategy following a harmonized data model to provide scalable access without duplication using zero-copy delta share technology.

SAP BDC serves as the foundation for your data and AI projects leveraging SAP managed and custom data products, including our growing open partner ecosystem with Databricks and the newly announced partnerships with Google Big Query, Snowflake and Microsoft Fabric.

 

My top features in 2025

Picking my top features for all of 2025 was not easy and here is my top feature list in no particular order.

 

Object store (general availability)

In 2025 we delivered the option to include an object store next to the well-known SAP HANA Cloud based persistency for a cost-efficient storage. You can use the existing tooling you already know to now create local tables on files, use replication flows, transformation flows which are then using Spark as compute engine - all orchestrated by task chains. You can load large quantities of data via replication flows and prepare the data using transformation flows and then share data to other spaces to be used as a source for additional flows, views, and of course analytic models. A really great enhancement!

 

Versioning of data builder objects

Object versioning has been introduced for views, analytic models, data access controls, and local tables. The new object versions are created automatically at the time of deployment which allows you now to list the past versions of objects, open a past version in read-only mode in a new tab, download a past version to a CSN/JSON file and restore a past version to replace the current version.

Be aware that the saving of an error-free restored version overwrites the current object. It is also important to understand that the versioning happens for the metadata of an object and not the data.

 

Efficiency features

Then there are tons of smaller enhancements that have been delivered in 2025 to increase efficiency and productivity overall. Let me just name a few here for the different components of Datasphere.

Analytic model

  •  stacking and reusing of models
  •  support for structures and data access controls for analytic models
  •  we introduced a measure-dependency graph, the fiscal time dimension and unit conversion
  •  and many enhancements with variables and parameters

Replication flows

  • delta only load type
  • support for views
  • reusing of source objects in multiple flows
  • many new sources and targets

Transformation flows

  • batch processing
  • parameter support
  • HANA tables as source in Spark transformation flows
  • other features bringing Spark transformation flows almost on par with HANA Cloud based ones

Task chains

  • deep retry of failed tasks in nested task chains
  • Rest API
  • Parameter support
  • notification tasks
  • amongst other improvements

Catalog

  • Support for SAP BW/4HANA, seamless planning, SAP BDC data products, Databricks via BDC connect
  • GenAI-assisted generation of catalog asset descriptions and classifications
  • Mass import of existing glossaries, terms, KPI’s, etc. from flat files

 

SAP Cloud application lifecycle management

SAP Datasphere is now integrated into SAP Cloud application lifecycle management (ALM) for health, job and automation monitoring.

Health monitoring enables you to check the health of one or more Datasphere tenants from the Health Monitoring app in Cloud ALM to check on 

  • Memory and Disk usage
  • Out of Memory Events
  • Task Failures and
  • Admission Control Events

Job and automation monitoring enables you to monitor the tasks runs and executions in one or more SAP Datasphere tenants from the Job and Automation Monitoring app in Cloud ALM.

The integration overall eases the monitoring of an SAP Datasphere tenant in a complex customer landscape with a centralized, consistent way of tracking the tenants.

In addition, the early watch alert reports are now also available for SAP Datasphere. EWA is an automatic service analyzing the essential administrative areas of your SAP systems and covered by your maintenance agreement.

 

Data access controls based on IdP attributes

Data access controls based on identity provider (IdP) attributes are a small enhancement, but it is very powerful. You can now use values in custom attributes provided by your IdP as identifiers in your data access controls and define conditions that apply to users with these values. It is powerful because using these attributes allows you to apply a single condition to all users whose accounts contain that specific attribute value. In other words, you can group users with attributes to assign permissions to a group instead of individual users.

 

YouTube feature highlights of 2025

 

 

 

And more feature highlights of 2025

There are so many more great features which we delivered in 2025, so in addition to my 2025 top features, I pulled together the 2025 feature highlights in all different areas of SAP Datasphere for you. Enjoy the ride!

Data Integration

 

 

Catalog & Monitoring

 

Data Modelling

 

Miscellaneous

 

What exactly is rewiring for SAP Datasphere?

I have heard that question so many times over the last few months from customers, partners, but also SAP colleagues at events like SAP TechEd in Berlin or Sydney. 
During these discussions I observed that people unintentionally misinterpret the term “rewiring”. It sounds technical, hence there are associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

entry.title: Re: How to Claim Badges for Completed SAP Learning Courses?
entry.content:
Hi @deiamolina,

You can check whether you have completed the course and received the SAP badge in the “My Learning” > “My Activity” > “Completed” section of learning.sap.com.

If your course does not appear under the “Completed” tab, please check the “In Progress” section. There may be a missing quiz that has not yet been completed. If you followed the course across multiple sessions, it can also happen that progress is not saved if you were not logged in during one of the sessions.

Please also note that “Course Completion Badges” are not issued on Credly. They are only accessible through the “My Learning Activity” section on learning.sap.com, according to the Digital Badges - General FAQ.

I hope this helps you.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: Question Regarding SAP Customer Checkout Exchange Rat...
entry.content:
Hello,

If the POS is running UZS(receipt currency), and payment are made in UZS - then there is no exchange rate to use. So exchange rate is 1.

If the POS is running UZS(receipt currency), and the payment is made in foreign currency(example EUR), only then the exchange rate maintained in used and in the Incoming payment, you will see the exchange rate.

If your B1 is running in a different currency and your PoS is running in a different currency, then thats something else.
We need to understand, discuss and look for custom solution by modification of scenarios(using extension concept). 

Best Regards,
Bikash Bansal

BTP Trial Cockpit home page has currently an issue that clicking on 'Go To Your Trial Account' button is not working (i.e. does not navigate users to the 'Account Explorer' page)

If you don't want to wait until the fix is available you could try this workaround to enter your trial subaccount directly:

-- Filter to see the get requests

-- select Response tab

open https://cockpit.hanatrial.ondemand.com/trial/#/globalaccount/<trial-global-account-guid>

Hope that helps?

Best regards, Jens

entry.title: The Problem: The "Static Wall" of Traditional Design
entry.content:
What is Generative UI?
Generative UI (GenUI) is a paradigm shift where the user interface is created, modified, or rearranged by AI in real-time. Instead of a static set of screens, the interface is a "chameleon" that reshapes itself based on the user's intent and context.

The Mechanics: How the Interface "Assembles" Itself
We’re moving away from "hard-coded" layouts toward a system of Real-time Assembly. You aren't letting an AI guess how to code a website from scratch; instead, you are giving it a brain and a toolbox.

Intent Decoding: The system analyzes the user’s natural language or behavior to identify the specific goal (e.g., "I need to compare these three service plans").
Component Orchestration: The AI selects the best visual tools from a library of pre-defined, high-quality building blocks such as interactive tables, scheduling widgets, or data visualizations.
Contextual Mapping: The system fetches the relevant data and maps it into the selected components, ensuring the right information sits in the right place.
On-Demand Rendering: The interface is delivered instantly to the user’s screen, appearing only when the logic of the conversation or task requires it.

Generative UI is a powerful evolution, but it requires a strategic balance.

The Advantages
Hyper-Personalization: The interface meets the user where they are, adapting to their skill level, their current device, and the specific complexity of their task.
Intuitive Discovery: It eliminates "feature fatigue." Instead of users hunting through complex navigation, the specific tool they need finds them.
Adaptive Accessibility: The UI can reshape itself to meet individual needs, automatically adjusting layouts, contrast, or simplicity for different accessibility requirements.
Systemic Scalability: Design and development teams can focus on building robust, reusable systems rather than spending time on every possible edge-case screen.

The Challenges
Consistency & Habit: Users rely on "muscle memory." If the interface changes too drastically every time it's used, it can create a sense of disorientation.
Reliability & Logic: Just as AI can produce incorrect text, it can potentially assemble a UI that is visually impressive but logically flawed or functionally broken.
Performance Overhead: Generating and rendering custom components on the fly requires more processing power and lower latency than serving a static page.
Contextual Privacy: To be truly helpful, these systems require deep context about the user’s intent, necessitating a higher standard for data security and transparent handling.

The Verdict: Designing Systems, Not Pages
Generative UI represents the end of the "one-size-fits-all" software era. We are shifting from designing static pages to designing intelligent systems that can assemble themselves.

In this new world, the most successful interface won't be the one with the most features but it will be the one that is "smart" enough to get out of the user's way and provide exactly what they need, the moment they need it.

Are you ready to move beyond the static screen and start building "living" interfaces?

Yes, we do transfer the exchange rate from CCO to B1. So if the local currency in B1 is USD and the local currency in CCO is UZS you need to maintain an exchange rate in CCO => Currency => Exchange Rate between UZS and USD.

entry.title: Best practices for Process Modelling in SAP Build Process Automation to use in SAP Ariba Intake Mngt
entry.content:
In this blog, we share best practices that you can apply to develop processes in SAP Build Process Automation with the specific intent to publish and deploy them as Intake Request Types for the SAP Ariba Intake Management solution.

Make use of the existing documentation

Use SAP Build Process Automation

Explore the available learnings

Re-use action-structures

If you are using actions, the according structures are generated into your project and you can re-use them directly.

Use data types

If you use structures aside from actions, create them as data type in SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA), so you can re-use them at any point in your project. Otherwise, you would have to define them in each input/output of each step you use them in.

Create custom variables

If you need a variable to be available in the whole process then create a custom variable. Custom variables can also make use of created data types.

Use constants

Using constants will avoid typo-based errors in evaluations/comparisons. SBPA does not provide such a thing in the editor, but you can use a custom variable with a default value as a replacement for a constant.

Actions, numbers, and strings

When an action is created via an interface description, fields that are of type EDMX.Decimal will be transformed to “string” in order to avoid truncation issues. If your process is using input that has been defined as “number”, use a script task to convert the number into a string (e.g. via the toString() function) before using it as an input to the action.

Actions and deep mapping

If actions are being used to trigger APIs with deep nested structures (e.g. the Purchase Order API in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), the complete structure depth will not be offered in the process editor for mapping. You can use a script task to create an according object as a custom variable and select “bind Object” in the according action input.

How to disable type checking in the script editor

The script editor is checking the complex types you are using within it. For complex structures it will require you to set a value to a field, even if the field is not mandatory. In such cases you can hide the type-information from the editor:

// import the item data from the context
// ignore type information to prevent clashes with editor
var orderItem = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(
$.context.action_getAPurchaseOrderItem.result.d));
…
// take over the table of account assignments into the PO item
orderItem.to_AccountAssignment = (orderItem.to_AccountAssignment.results && orderItem.to_AccountAssignment.results.length > 0) ? orderItem.to_AccountAssignment : undefined
…

// create POI object with results array
var POI = {
  results: [orderItem]
}

// write the created item data to a custom variable 
// but ignore type information (again) to prevent clashes with editor
$.context.custom.poi = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(POI))

Now the custom variable “POI” can be used to populate the deep nested to_PurchaseOrderItem input of a “Create Purchase Order” action:

 

Capture the output of a “Wait for API call” step

The “Wait for API call” steps have outputs that unfortunately can’t be used directly as an input for the next upcoming step. Use a script task to take over the value into a custom variable.

Use sub-processes

If you are creating complex approval workflows, the usage of sub-processes may help to master the complexity. They allow to cut a huge process into smaller manageable pieces. They also help to visualise milestones in the process.

Consider the usage of template variants

It also will give some degree of flexibility, compared to a pure predefined process running in a SaaS environment. You start with a normal process project. There you can add a “Variant Template” step via the “+” anywhere into your process flow. This can be compared to adding an extension point, where (restricted) custom logic can be added in the form of predefined sub-processes.

If you open the editor, you can add sub-processes to it, define inputs/outputs, and general constraints, for example if a step is required or if there is a maximum number of usages. With the “Variant Editor” you also need to create a default variant. Then a “Variant Management” project needs to be created (see here) and maintained as a dependency in the process project. This way an app can be offered to the customer that allows to define and manage variants. The variants that are available can automatically be chosen by predefined rules. If there is no rule in place, the default variant will be chosen.

entry.title: How to set up a custom process within SAP Ariba Intake Management
entry.content:
In this blog, you will learn how to set up a custom process that you have developed yourself in SAP Build Process Automation and that you want to run within SAP Ariba Intake Management.

Setting up a request type

When setting up a new request type in SAP Ariba Intake Management (see Configuring Intake Request Types), it is possible to integrate two kinds of processes:

Pre-delivered Processes

These processes run in the SAP-managed customer subaccount. These process are restricted in their access since the customers and partners cannot access the subaccount that is managed by SAP.  Customers or partners can run the pre-delivered process as it has been delivered. Only if SAP delivers variants of the process, can the customer or partner make modification. The ability to modify the variant will depend if SAP has exposed any SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) artefacts for editing.

Custom Processes

Custom Processes run in the customer managed subaccount owned by the customer (or managed on behalf of a partner). Customers and partners can view or modify the process in the SAP Build Process Automation process editor. Moreover, they can develop new ones. Note however, that SAP does not provide any maintenance or support for customer managed processes. SAP delivers an example process per default (“Return Item”) as a template for a typical custom process.

Make a custom process available in configuration app “Configure Intake Request Types”

Follow the documentation on Connecting your own SAP Build ProcessAutomation Instance and creating your own Processes for SAP Ariba Intake Management.

Before you can start to develop your own SBPA processes and deploy them, you must set up and connect your customer managed SBPA instance and connect it to SAP Ariba Intake Management. The essential steps on how to set up destinations and relationships to SAP Cloud Identity services are described in Connecting Your Own SAP Build Process Automation Instance.

Once the customer managed SBPA instance is connected to intake management, you can create a new request type by clicking on configuration -> Configure Intake Request Types -> Create. In the new request type select “Custom Process” and then choose your process Id from the value help and maintain the URL of the Application. Maintain all other mandatory fields and save the request type.

We assume that a custom process is started via a Fiori UI and that the process defined in SBPA includes a start trigger. Intake Management will not automatically notice if a new SBPA process instance has been created. To ensure that the intake process instances become visible on the Intake Dashboard, the direct call of the trigger must be re-routed via the intake core service. The intake core service will start the SBPA process and persist a link to the process instance. This way the new process instance will also be displayed in the intake dashboard. To achieve this, the intake core service offers an API. This API needs to be called from your UI5 Application.

The URL can be constructed from:

  • The application name you have used to deploy your UI5 application. You can find it in your customer managed subaccount, in the BTP-Cockpit under “HTML5 Applications” in the column “Application Name”. (referred to as “<your HTML5 app name>” in the example code below)

  • The API path “/intake-api/api/Intake/v1/
  • The action name “startIntake”

The following code snippets show how the start of an SBPA process can be triggered via the intake core service. The assumption is, that this code is part of an UI5 App, deployed in a customer managed subaccount. To make the code below work, the destination intake_api needs to be set up and a dependency to SAP Cloud Identity Services must be created, as described in the documentation linked above.

Provide the process parameters as parameters to your HTML5 App

If you have built your own SBPA process, this process may have parameters it can be started with. To reveal these parameters to the AI features of SAP Ariba Intake Management, they need to be sent into your HTML5 App as startup parameters. That way, if your process is being recommended by the AI as a request type, the AI can already prefill some or all related parameters from the conversation content with the end user. This way you can pre-populate fields with the values and the end user will have to fill in less information into your HTML5 App.

To take over the values from the startup parameters, follow the documentation on Deploying a UI in SAP Build Process Automation (Option 2).

startSbpaProcess: function () {
    var payload = {
    //extract the parameter intakeConfigurationID 
    //from the parameters your application has been started with.

    //the payloads ”Parameters” reflect the importing parameters 
    //of your SBPA process. Extract the according values from the parameters your 
    //application has been started with and merge it with the end users input
    IntakeConfigurationID: ”your intakeConfigurationID” ,
    IntakeInstanceID: "your intakeInstanceID") || null,
    Parameters: [
        {
          Name: "simpleValueName",
          Value: {value: "simpleValue"}
        },
        {
          Name: "structuredParameter",
          Value:
              {
                value: [
                    {
                        “member1”: valueOfMember1,
                        “member2”: valueOfMember2,
                        “member3”: valueOfMember3,
                    }
                ]
          }
        }
     ]
  };
  _startTheProcess(payload);
};

 

_startTheProcess: function (payload) {
    let sUrl = 
"<your HTML5 app name>/intake-api/api/Intake/v1/startIntake"; 
    // Make an AJAX POST request to initiate the workflow
      $.ajax({
        url: sUrl, 
        method: "POST", 
        async: false, 
        contentType: "application/json",
        },
        data: JSON.stringify(payload), 
        success: function (result) {
          console.info("started workflow:");
        },
        error: function (request) {
        // Parse and log the error response
          var errorResponse = JSON.parse(request.responseText);
          console.error("Error starting workflow:", errorResponse);
        }
    });
},

Further documentation on the API can be found on:

  • Setup and configuration of SAP Ariba Intake Management
  • https://api.sap.com/ (search for:” Intake Request” or “SAP Ariba Intake Management”)

entry.title: Best practice on process modelling to enable process visibility in SAP Ariba Intake Management
entry.content:
As a pre-requisite, you must ensure that your SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA) project contains at least a main process, where all the steps of the process are defined. If you aim to visualise certain major milestones within the process, you can do that by using a combination of sub-processes and “Wait for API call” steps. Create a business document via your own microservice and make your implementation also receive status updates for the business documents it creates. Your own microservice can now call the SBPA process instance and pass the updated status.

Sub-Processes:

Represent the milestones in this context. You can create a sub-process either directly on the canvas using the “+” in between process steps, or upfront on the overview tab, using the create button. The sub-processes can be used for deeper structuring complex processes, but for visualising the milestones only, they do not have to contain any steps.

Sub processes will be displayed in a UI component once they are done in the current flow:

Now that we have the milestones visualised, we also want to show the progress of the process over time. Usually a process will only pause, if there is a direct user input required for example via a form or an approval that is modelled inside the process. But when calling something outside of the process that introduces a delay, this can’t be represented in the process.

This could be for example an external API to create a Purchase Order in S/4. If there is an approval active within the S/4 system, the SBPA process would not wait for the approval to happen, it would continue directly after the creation of the PO. To pause a process in such a case, “Wait for API call” steps can be used.

Wait for API call steps:

The “Wait for API call” steps allow the process to pause in between two milestones, if next milestone is not reached yet. (also see Create a Wait for an API Call Trigger and 10 - Call 3rd-Party System and Wait for Callback)

With the help of the “Wait for API call” steps, you achieve two things:

  1. The process pauses at this step, until a call to the according API (trigger) happens from the outside.
  2. You can provide information into the process with that API call. By defining outputs for the wait step, you define the API that can be called later. The provided values can be evaluated later in the process

The “Wait for API call” steps can be re-used in the process. If there are several places in the process where you want to wait and evaluate the incoming API call, you just have to define an according “Wait for API call” step once. The places where the defined wait step is inserted, can also be individually renamed, which helps to keep the process organised.

Otherwise, if you are not re-using the “Wait for API call” steps, for each new one, a new API endpoint would be created.

Wait steps after an action are special

In general, for updating the status of a process, a single “wait for API call” step with a variable “status” as output would be sufficient, but there is also the case of performing an action first. In that case, in SAP Ariba intake Management, a separate step is created, that has the variables “error” and “id”. If the error variable is not empty, this indicates that the action did fail, otherwise the id needs to be populated with the id of the created document.

In general:

  • “Wait for API call” steps will create an according trigger in the project. This trigger is an API endpoint and can be re-used at different places in the process.
  • Every “Wait for API call” requires the id of the process instance as a parameter. It is also possible to provide additional parameters

How to model to make use of polling

A detailed description is shown in the sequence diagram below. 

If you are using your own microservice app-to-app authentication has to be set up as described in https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/java/security#app-to-app

If you do not use your own microservice, the API call to “startIntake” needs to be performed by the Wind-up UI directly and the API call to the “backend for business document creation” must be called via an action from the SBPA process. A later status update and display will then not be possible.
